periods.title: Foundations (brain, spinal cord, heart, early organs)
periods.summary: This is the build-the-blueprint stage. A lot happens fast, even before you may feel very pregnant.
development: Early brain and spinal cord structures form very early (neural tube).
The heart forms and begins working early on.
Early limb and facial structures begin to appear and take shape.
The placenta develops to support the rest of pregnancy.

notes.text: Weeks are counted from the first day of your last period (so week 1-2 happen before conception).
In general, the first trimester does not require extra calories. Focus on nutrient density.

nutrients.why: Folate is most time-sensitive early on because neural tube development happens very early.
nutrients.details: Neural tube defects occur very early in pregnancy, which is why folate adequacy before and early in pregnancy matters so much.

nutrients.why: Choline supports early brain and spinal cord development.
nutrients.details: Choline is involved in normal brain and spinal cord development and supports many cell processes.

nutrients.why: Zinc supports rapid cell growth and early tissue formation.
nutrients.details: Early development is a high-growth phase, and zinc is required for many enzymes and cell processes.

nutrients.why: Vitamin B-12 supports nervous system function and red blood cell formation.
nutrients.details: B-12 works closely with folate in key metabolic pathways and supports neurological function.

nutrients.why: Protein supports foundational growth of fetal and maternal tissue.
nutrients.details: Protein needs rise in pregnancy overall, and it supports growth of new tissues.

periods.title: Organ formation wraps up (now it's growth + refinement)
periods.summary: By the end of this period, the baby is fully formed with organs and limbs in place, then shifts toward growth and maturation.
development: Major internal organs continue developing and refining.
By about 12 weeks, organs, muscles, limbs, and bones are in place and development shifts toward growth and maturation.
Placenta development continues and becomes fully formed around this stage.

notes.text: In general, the first trimester does not require extra calories. Focus on nutrient density.

nutrients.why: Folate remains a key foundation nutrient in early pregnancy.
nutrients.details: Folate supports normal cell division and is emphasized in pregnancy guidance.

nutrients.why: Rapid growth continues, and zinc supports many growth and development processes.
nutrients.details: Zinc is required for numerous enzymes and supports immune function and growth.

nutrients.why: This is a major growth period and protein supports new tissue.
nutrients.details: Protein needs increase in pregnancy and support fetal and maternal tissue growth.

nutrients.why: Vitamin B-6 supports metabolism and red blood cell formation.
nutrients.details: B-6 is involved in many metabolic processes important during pregnancy.

periods.title: Brain + skeleton momentum
periods.summary: You're in the second trimester: growth accelerates and coordination and movement increase.
development: Swallowing begins and kidneys start to work.
Hearing and light sensitivity begin to emerge.
Facial muscles and nervous system development allow more movement and early expressions.

notes.text: Second trimester often means about 340 extra calories/day, depending on your starting weight and situation.

nutrients.why: DHA is a key building block for the developing brain and eyes.
nutrients.details: Omega-3s (including DHA) are structural components in the brain and retina; many people don't get enough from food.

nutrients.why: Choline supports brain and nervous system development.
nutrients.details: Choline is involved in normal brain and spinal cord development and supports many cellular processes.

nutrients.why: As the skeleton develops, calcium becomes increasingly important.
nutrients.details: Calcium is essential for bone structure and is emphasized in pregnancy nutrition guidance.

nutrients.why: Vitamin D helps with calcium use and bone development.
nutrients.details: Vitamin D supports calcium absorption and is relevant to skeletal development.

nutrients.why: Protein supports overall growth as the fetus gets bigger each week.
nutrients.details: Protein needs increase in pregnancy and support new tissue growth.

periods.title: Movement + senses (a very active stretch)
periods.summary: This period is often when movement becomes obvious, and the fetus keeps building capacity for life outside the womb.
development: Fingerprints and nails form; grip strengthens.
Movement increases and responses to sound can begin.
Weight gain starts to accelerate and the fetus begins to "fill out" over time.

notes.text: Second trimester often means about 340 extra calories/day, depending on your starting weight and situation.

nutrients.why: Iron supports red blood cell production and oxygen delivery for both you and the fetus.
nutrients.details: Iron needs increase in pregnancy and iron deficiency is common; adequacy supports healthy red blood cells.

nutrients.why: Growth is the main job right now, and protein is the main building material.
nutrients.details: Protein needs rise in pregnancy overall and support fetal growth.

nutrients.why: Brain and nervous system development continues all pregnancy long.
nutrients.details: Omega-3s (including DHA) contribute to brain and retina structure.

nutrients.why: Vitamin C supports collagen formation and helps improve iron absorption from plant foods.
nutrients.details: Vitamin C is involved in collagen synthesis and can increase nonheme iron absorption.

periods.title: Lungs practice + viability threshold
periods.summary: The fetus practices breathing movements, and around 24 weeks the chance of survival begins if born early (with intensive care).
development: The placenta continues growing (though the baby weighs more than the placenta from around this stage).
Breathing movements are practiced, though lungs are not yet ready to work fully.
By about 24 weeks, survival becomes possible if born very early, but risks remain.

notes.text: Second trimester often means about 340 extra calories/day, depending on your starting weight and situation.

nutrients.why: Iron supports expanding maternal blood volume and fetal needs.
nutrients.details: Pregnancy increases iron requirements; iron deficiency is common and matters for oxygen transport.

nutrients.why: A growth-and-maturation stretch: protein remains a core building block.
nutrients.details: Protein supports tissue growth for both fetus and mother during pregnancy.

nutrients.why: Vitamin C supports tissue structure and can help with iron absorption.
nutrients.details: Vitamin C supports collagen and can improve absorption of iron from plant foods.

nutrients.why: Zinc supports growth and immune function.
nutrients.details: Zinc is involved in many enzyme systems and supports immune and growth processes.

periods.title: More fat, more brain, more readiness
periods.summary: Growth continues and the fetus becomes "perfectly formed" by this stage, while still needing major maturation.
development: Responses to sound and touch are strong; hiccups can happen.
Eyelids can open around this time and the baby keeps gaining weight.
Brain, lungs, and digestive system are formed but still maturing.

notes.text: Third trimester begins around week 28. Calorie needs typically rise to about +450/day for many people.

nutrients.why: DHA supports ongoing brain and eye development, which is very active late pregnancy.
nutrients.details: Omega-3s (including DHA) are structural components in the brain and retina.

nutrients.why: Iron supports blood and oxygen delivery and helps prevent anemia.
nutrients.details: Iron needs increase in pregnancy; adequacy supports red blood cell production.

nutrients.why: This is still a growth-heavy window and protein supports tissue expansion.
nutrients.details: Protein supports fetal growth and maternal tissue changes during pregnancy.

nutrients.why: Bone development continues, and calcium supports skeletal structure.
nutrients.details: Calcium is essential for bones and is emphasized in pregnancy guidance.

periods.title: Lungs develop rapidly; positioning for birth
periods.summary: A high-growth stretch: lungs develop rapidly and many babies start moving into a head-down position.
development: Sucking reflex develops and practice continues.
Lungs develop rapidly, though full readiness is later.
Many babies shift toward a head-down position by around 32 weeks.

notes.text: Third trimester calorie needs often rise to about +450/day for many people.

nutrients.why: Protein supports the rapid growth and maturation happening now.
nutrients.details: Protein needs rise in pregnancy overall and support growth of fetal and maternal tissues.

nutrients.why: Iron supports oxygen delivery and helps prevent anemia as demands remain high.
nutrients.details: Iron needs increase in pregnancy and iron deficiency is common.

nutrients.why: Bone mineral needs continue as the fetus gets larger.
nutrients.details: Calcium is essential for skeletal structure.

nutrients.why: Vitamin D supports calcium use and bone development.
nutrients.details: Vitamin D helps the body absorb calcium and supports bone health.

periods.title: Final development + weight gain
periods.summary: The baby's systems are largely in place; the focus is on maturing and preparing for delivery.
development: Brain and nervous system development continues.
Your baby's body keeps gaining weight and smoothing out.
Readiness for breathing improves as lungs keep developing.

notes.text: Third trimester calorie needs often rise to about +450/day for many people.

nutrients.why: Iron supports maternal and fetal blood needs late in pregnancy.
nutrients.details: Iron needs increase in pregnancy and adequacy matters for red blood cell production.

nutrients.why: Protein supports ongoing growth and tissue repair and preparation for birth.
nutrients.details: Protein supports growth of new tissue during pregnancy.

nutrients.why: Bone structure continues to mature as birth approaches.
nutrients.details: Calcium is essential for bones and teeth.

nutrients.why: Vitamin D supports calcium absorption and bone health.
nutrients.details: Vitamin D helps the body use calcium effectively.

periods.title: Full term: finishing touches
periods.summary: Full-term begins around 37 weeks. At this point, it's mostly about final maturation and steady nourishment.
development: Baby is considered full-term around 37 weeks and ready to be born in the coming weeks.
Lanugo is mostly gone by around 40 weeks for many babies.
The baby continues to prepare for birth and life outside the womb.

notes.text: Third trimester calorie needs often rise to about +450/day for many people.

nutrients.why: Protein supports steady nourishment and maternal recovery needs.
nutrients.details: Protein supports tissue maintenance and repair during pregnancy.

nutrients.why: Iron supports red blood cells and helps prevent anemia late pregnancy.
nutrients.details: Iron needs remain elevated in pregnancy and deficiency is common.

nutrients.why: Calcium supports bones and teeth as growth completes.
nutrients.details: Calcium is essential for skeletal structure.

nutrients.why: Vitamin D supports calcium use and bone health.
nutrients.details: Vitamin D helps with calcium absorption.
